Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Mining Intentions on Social Media to Enhance Situational Awareness of Crisis Response Organizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In large-scale emergencies, people post a lot of information about their status, needs, and abilities to help on social media. In principle, these posts might help emergency management teams get a better picture of the situation and find useful resources, but the number and questionable accuracy of these posts make them less useful than they could be. This project is about developing tools that identify people's intentions related to the emergency, sorting tweets into categories such as requests for help or information, offers of help, announcements of their safety or location, and so on. This problem of intent inference is a key scientific problem in natural language processing and artificial intelligence, with practical uses in a number of areas beyond emergency management, including web search and providing location-aware services. The researchers will attack the intent inference problem by narrowing it to the emergency response domain. First, they will work closely with emergency response teams to identify meaningful categories of intent that align with emergency response needs, in order to guide the collection and labeling of social media posts. Then, they will develop strategies drawn from existing image and natural language processing techniques and informed by the emergency response context to do the categorization work. Finally, they will build and evaluate a tool that uses the categorization algorithms to highlight the social media posts that are most likely to be useful to emergency responders. The work will be used to help develop courses around data science at the lead researcher's school, and the tools will be made publicly available through an open source code and advertised to communities of interest.

To build the set of crisis-specific intent categories, the research team will first analyze existing operational manuals for emergency response including the Incident-Command-System models to extract key processes and initial categories, then refine that set working with experts from the Fairfax Fire and Rescue Department, an advisory committee of social media working group for emergency services at Department of Homeland Security that has members across the country, and members of the project's advisory board. Intent extraction will be modeled as a multilabel classification problem on two dimensions: type of intent, and topical category; this formulation maps well to characteristics of posts (which might contain multiple intents and topics) and scopes the complexity of general intent inference. Datasets will be gathered from prior crisis events and labeled by crowd workers interested in humanitarian work according to the categories identified from the first phase. Features of posts will be constructed from posts? metadata using natural language processing techniques on textual content, image processing techniques on multimedia content and author profiling techniques. Features will include extracting syntactic-semantic patterns that represent declarative and psycholinguistic knowledge as well as ideas from discourse analysis, while features of authors will be drawn from their provided profile information as well as aggregate inferences from their posts. The team will use a multi-task learning framework as the underlying algorithm to leverage relationships between the different categories to be classified. Finally, the developed interface will support faceted browsing by intent, topic, location, and response management process, and be evaluated through training exercises with the research team's practitioner partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The public shares a variety of information about their status, needs, and abilities to help on social media during disasters. Some of these posts might help emergency services in improving the understanding of the evolving situation on the ground for optimizing response time, as well as timely responding to the critical calls for help. However, quickly finding such posts from the social media data streams is challenging for human eyes due to the large-scale of the data. Even to create automated algorithms for finding such posts, the noisy, unstructured, and ungrammatical nature of user-generated content of social media presents challenges. Thus, this project has developed efficient automated algorithms and tools that rely on identifying user intentions from social media posts related to the response operations of emergency services and help sort relevant Twitter posts into categories such as serviceable requests/calls for help at large scale. 

The intellectual merit of this project includes the design, development, and validation of novel supervised and transfer learning algorithms for intent inference and relevance ranking of social media posts during disasters to assist emergency services. The resulting transfer learning methods can efficiently leverage historic disaster datasets to discover generalizable patterns to apply in a new disaster, which could save time spent in labeling data and training models for the new disaster. Further, the resulting method for ranking and grouping semantically similar posts of serviceable requests for help (e.g., transportation and medical categories) reduces redundancy and cognitive load for the emergency service worker. The project also developed a ranking method that remains aware of the human workload and lets the service worker control for the quality and quantity of filtered and ranked social media posts. This approach facilitates greater human control over the autonomy of the computational system and ensures respecting the contextual constraints of the work of the service worker. The above research has resulted in designing a social media filtering tool (CitizenHelper) with an active learning-based interface to adjust with the worker feedback and assist emergency services for operational support. The tool design is also flexible for use in their simulated training exercises.  

The broader impact of this project includes mentoring of two doctoral students, three masters students, and one undergraduate student, who contributed to over 15 peer-reviewed publications, two book chapters, one best paper award at an IEEE & ACM sponsored international conference, and multiple demonstrations of tool prototypes to filter social media streams for emergency services. One of the book chapters focused on the topic of social media for disaster management, and it was written in collaboration with an emergency management practitioner to improve the researcher-practitioner engagement and outreach to the practitioner community as well as its educational programs. Further, the project has shared annotated datasets of social media posts with intent and serviceability relevance labels. This resource could be leveraged to support future research in disaster informatics, social media mining, and human-centered computing, as well as to enrich the data science curriculum at universities for hands-on projects on real-world applications. PI has given multiple invited talks based on the results and activities of this research project, including one at the Data Science Exchange Seminar Series of the Analytics Center of Excellence at the U.S. Social Security Administration Headquarters. Lastly, the outcome of CitizenHelper tool from this project was adapted for COVID-19 pandemic response by the Community Emergency Response Teams (CERTs) led by Montgomery County CERT in the Washington D.C. Metro region for real-time social media processing and this was supported by a new NSF RAPID grant project for human-AI teaming for information filtering.
